message.content:
## Initial Candidates

Stage 1 identified the following candidates based on white-capped mushroom with ring on grassland near oak trees:

- **Field Mushroom (Agaricus campestris)** — high confidence — white cap, ring, grassland habitat
- **Horse Mushroom (Agaricus arvensis)** — medium confidence — white cap, ring, grassland
- **Death Cap (Amanita phalloides)** — medium confidence — ring, oak association is significant
- **Yellow Stainer (Agaricus xanthodermus)** — low confidence — white Agaricus lookalike

## Verification

### Field Mushroom (Agaricus campestris)
| Feature | You described | Dataset says | Verdict |
|---------|--------------|-------------|--------|
| Cap colour | white | white to grey-brown | MATCH |
| Ring | ring present | thin ring, often disappearing | MATCH |
| Habitat | grassland | grassland, meadows, pastures | MATCH |
| Gills | not described | deep pink when young, darkening to brown | MISSING |
| Volva | not described | absent — no volva | MISSING |

**Overall**: Partial match — cap and habitat consistent, but critical features (gills, stem base) not described
**Edibility**: Edible and popular, BUT dangerous confusion species exist

### Death Cap (Amanita phalloides)
| Feature | You described | Dataset says | Verdict |
|---------|--------------|-------------|--------|
| Cap colour | white | olive green to dirty yellow, occasionally pale | PARTIAL MATCH |
| Ring | ring present | prominent skirt-like ring | MATCH |
| Habitat | near oak | broadleaf woodland, especially oak | MATCH |
| Volva | not described | large sac-like volva at base | MISSING |
| Gills | not described | white to cream, free | MISSING |

**Overall**: Cannot eliminate — oak association is significant, and young/pale Death Caps can appear whitish
**Edibility**: DEADLY — contains amatoxins

### Horse Mushroom (Agaricus arvensis)
| Feature | You described | Dataset says | Verdict |
|---------|--------------|-------------|--------|
| Cap colour | white | white to yellowish | MATCH |
| Ring | ring present | large, persistent ring | MATCH |
| Habitat | grassland | grassland, meadows | MATCH |

**Overall**: Partial match — consistent with description but needs gill check
**Edibility**: Edible

## Assessment

This description matches both **Agaricus** (edible) and **Amanita** (deadly) species. The proximity to oak trees is critical — this is exactly where Death Cap (Amanita phalloides) occurs. Without checking the stem base for a volva, this cannot be safely identified.

## What Would Help

The single most important check: carefully dig around the stem base and look for a cup, sack, or bag-like structure (volva). If there is any volva present, this is Amanita, NOT Agaricus — do not eat it. Also check gill colour: Agaricus gills start pink and darken to brown; Amanita gills stay white.

## Safety Notes

⚠️ **Death Cap warning**: Any white mushroom with a ring near oak trees MUST be checked for a volva at the base. Amanita phalloides (Death Cap) is deadly and looks superficially similar to edible Agaricus species. Always dig up the full base when picking white-capped mushrooms.
